column4: Hi again. I am on my way to patch my wireless card for using aircrack (IT Security Lecture at university). The manual says I need to decide which kernel version I am useing (3.2 or newer) or (older kerlnels)
Do they mean my linux kernel (I guess it's 3.0) or a "wireless kernel" if this exists
there is no such thing as a wireless kernel
the fact that you are not comfortable with this inforamtion suggests you should not be trying to patch the kernel
I very very VERY strongly advise you not to try to patch the kernel at your current ability
thanks for the advise; but I need to based on my lecture. I guess it can only kick ubuntu down; so I need to reinstall it.
I doubt your lecture forces you to do something like this
We need to simulate an attack on a wireless lan and present the results... there is no further support... but that's my problem :-)
have you considered using a distro that is aimed to do that
with the utmost respect, how can you give a lecture on something like this when you have no understanding of how to use/manage the tool
why not a modern backtrack install
my hardware is completely not supporter. I tried it before.
backtrack is based on ubuntu
so if ubuntu works, backtrack will work

what version of backtrack have you tried ?
ok, that is very old, try a modern version, backtrack 4 - 5

I promise using a distro that is built to do what you want rather than trying to patch the ubuntu kernel, will be a lot lot easier

no, and you're using wubi, bad idea
if you are going to do a job - do it right, get a distro like back track, install it properly in a dual boot setup
